Award.AwardTitle: Graduate Summer School in Modern Harmonic Analysis and Its Applications
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award provides funding to help defray the expenses of participants in the "Graduate Summer School in Modern Harmonic Analysis and Its Applications" that will be held July 20-August 7, 2015, at the College Park campus of the University of Maryland. This summer school for graduate students will focus on modern harmonic analysis and applications, specifically, topics from Fourier and time-frequency analysis, finite frame theory, sparse transforms, and geometric and analytic methods for modeling big data. The instruction comprises seven four-day-long lecture series, including a tutorial, supplemented by computer lab work. The objectives are to quickly review the fundamentals, focus on the developments of the last 10 years, and provide a glimpse of the state of current research and open problems. Most of this information is available only in the form of original research papers or preprints; the summer school is intended to make this material accessible to graduate students, postdoctoral researchers, and other nonspecialists.

This summer school, which is jointly sponsored by the University of Maryland and the Institute for Mathematics and Its Applications (IMA) through the latter's IMA Participating Institution Graduate Student Summer Program, brings together some of the leading harmonic analysts in the U.S. to explore topics that lie at the heart of modern harmonic analysis. The primary topics of the courses (with the corresponding lecturers) are the following: Fourier analysis (John Benedetto); frames and time-freqency analysis (Chris Heil); preconditioning of finite frames (Kasso Okoudjou); nonlinear analysis with frames (Radu Balan); sparse Fourier transforms (Anna Gilbert); geometric and analytic methods for modeling data, and their application (Gilad Lerman); and harmonic analysis of big data (Wojtek Czaja).

Summer School web site: www.norbertwiener.umd.edu/Education/IMA2015/

POR.DRECONTENT:
The grant provided partial support for the 3-week summer graduate school on Harmonic Analysis and Aplicationsat the University of Maryland, College Park, MD, July 20-August 7, 2015. The NSF funds complemented the IMA (University of Minnesota) support that was only used for attendees from IMA participating institutions.

Modern Harmonic Analysis encompasses areas as diverse as group representation theory, functional analysis and applications in signal processing, machine learning and data analysis. These techniques deliver the desired answers by engineers and scientists working with big data sets or searching for novel methods to connect experiments with theory. With the new form of the Moore's Law where CPU clock frequency doubling is replaced by parallel processing, the applied mathematics community is now faced with a new paradigm.

The summer school involved 67 participants from all over the world, including 8 lecturers and 6 teaching assistants. The program website was mentained by the Norbert Wiener Center at the University of Maryland and can be accessed here: http://www.norbertwiener.umd.edu/Education/IMA2015/

The 8 lecturers were: Radu Balan (University of Maryland), John Benedetto (University of Maryland), Wojtek Czaja (University of Maryland), Anna Gilbert (University of Michigan), Chris Heil (Georgia Tech), Gilad Lerman (University of Minnesota), Kasso Okoudjou (University of Maryland), Nate Strawn (Georgetown University). Due to a serious accident, Gilad Lerman did not attend the school, but was heavily involved in planning and organization of the program. There were 30 lectures delivered by 7 instructors:

Fourier Analysis (John Benedetto, UMD)

Frames and Time-Frequency Analysis (Chris Heil, GaTech)

Preconditioning of Finite Frames (Kasso Okoudjou, UMD)

Nonlinear Analysis with Frames (Radu Balan, UMD)

Sparse Fourier Transform (Anna Gilbert, UM)

Dictionary Learning with Geometric Multiresolution Analysis and Data-Driven Convolutions (Nate Strawn, Georgetown University)

Harmonic Analysis and Big Data (Wojtek Czaja, UMD)

Ten more people were supported at the FFT (February Fourier Talks) 2017,  Conference, at the University of Maryland, February 16-17, 2017, a conference dedicated to the theory and applications of the Fourier and harmonic analysis. Out of the these ten participants, three were graduate students who attended the Harmonic Analysis and Applications Summer School in 2015.
